Happy to chime in. This has been a learning process for everyone, us included, and we are working hard to be transparent and originate quality debt. We are 100% committed to this process and want to see it be successful. I believe RWA and specifically, short term bridge loans, are relatively safe collateral type and we work hard to make sure we originate the best possible loans, to the best of our ability. Regarding risk, here is a great post from PeerStreet, which is a multi-billion dollar bridge loan aggregator and asset manager. They buy similar loans from originators across the country and hold them to maturity, and their risk profile is similar/higher than ours. So at the end of 2020, with 6766 loans on the books, 3.68% had foreclosure notice filed and only .53% went to REO, and out of those, only 0.31% had any principal loss. I believe this is another great data point proving the relative safety of the asset class. In our business, there are a few metrics that work well for measuring collateral valuation risk. Loan To Cost (LTC), is probably the most representative and accurate risk valuation on the entire loan, including rehab. We lend up to 90% LTC which is fairly standard in the industry. This means that the most qualified borrowers have to bring at least 10% equity to the table, and often more. Across the entire book currently on Tinlake, our average LTC is in the low 80s%. Another great metric is After Rehab Value (ARV), and we lend up to 75% ARV. This means that no loan can be above 75% of ARV. Loan to Value is a relatively good measure of the value today, and our average across Tinlake is in the low 70%. On a case by case basis, if there is very little rehab needed, LTV may be a bit above 85%, but on the average, is below that. The portfolio is well de-risked with the borrower equity and junior capital sitting above Maker’s investment. We will continue to strive to keep the covenant of total volume of loans with LTV above 85% to below 15%, which is were we are now. As we were starting off with 0 balance, as the portfolio grows, it will be further de-risked and diversified. And as I hope the Peerstreet article above illustrates, there is a fairly low risk of loss on these types of assets. For any material changes we communicate with Drop investors 2 weeks in advance via email. Perhaps this process needs to improve, we are completely open to that. This is new to us just like it is to everyone else, and we are committed to improving and making it a success.

The asset value displayed on Tinlake is not the underlying collateral value but rather it is the current valuation of the outstanding loan based on the NAV model (it takes some expected risk of default aswell as interestrate into account). The appraisals of the underlying assets, LTVs etc are shared privately with Maker and this is is what is used as the input for the dashboard that Seb publishes (and where this screenshot is from). On the average financing of 226,067 DAI this must be a bug that we are looking int. It seems the underlying graph also counts failed transactions. It took us some time to figure out why the numbers didn’t add up. Unfortunately the tinlake-subgraph is also indexing failed transactions which leads to certain borrow amounts to be counted in the aggregate (Asset 27 was counted as having borrowed 3 x 210k = 630k because there were 2 failed transactions). The on-chain data is correct and looking at the asset tab on the Tinlake Dapp shows you the correct data with an incorrect sum. We will address this in an update to the graph data in the coming days.

RWA in DeFi and Maker is a dream I’ve personally been working towards to since early 2018. Centrifuge has raised and spent millions on this topic and has published every single piece of infrastructure as open source code and publicly available legal agreements. I want to emphasize that we are in this for the long run and welcome everybody with aligned interests. We have overwhelmingly positive support for our work in the community by MKR holders (the most recent inclusion poll, Peoples Company which saw quite a bit of discussion in the fourm had 30k yes and 1.5k no votes). To answer your questions more specifically:   I could argue the opposite: Maker is extremely subsidized. Centrifuge has been developing our product in close collaboration with the Maker community over more than two years. In that time we have not received a single dollar from MakerDAO or the Maker Foundation. In that time we supported business development efforts to bring Asset Originators into DeFi at a time when no one believed this was possible. When it became clear that the foundation was unable to do any work on Real World Assets and the DAO would not be able to get together a legal domain team we started paying lawyers out of our own pocket to devise a strategy and this is still a major work on our end (our next step here is hiring independent directors). We hosted calls with our lawyers to answer questions. We proposed MIP22 and developed it along with @equivrel’s work on MIP21, we worked on the spells for our assets and short of the PSM probably wrote one of the technically most complicated components not developed by the PE team. All of this was done at our risk and at our cost.   Maker is funding less than 15% of all pools on Centrifuge. New Silver has been prioritizing drawing DAI from Maker as opposed to raising capital from other investors. It would be no problem to replace  Maker here. There are currently > 56 NS2-DROP token holders (see etherscan.io) and only 2.8M DAI of 7.2M DAI are funded through Maker.   The SPVs are not making any money. That might be a misunderstanding of yours. The SPV funnels all proceeds from any loans on its books to token holders (minus management fees to pay for tax filings etc.). The Asset Originators have different business models, some invest in the junior tranche, some charge an origination fee. In the instance of New Silver, they are an established and profitable business that has existed outside of our world of DeFi for a few years and is in good standing (as verified and described in the risk evaluation that was originally published) and they charge an origination fee but also have their own money in the junior tranche. Changing the rate doesn’t have any impact on this. The rate was adjusted to respond to market conditions. Remember this pool was launched during some of the darker times of the pandemic and higher interest rates were prudent at the time. @prankstr25 posted a good summary on the asset class and how it performed more recently a few posts up.   I am sure the community is not opposed and Maker could build something similar to the CropJoin adapter that was proposed for farming other rewards.

It’s not a black/white that RE mania means no safe fix and flip, it can be.  It is a sliding scale where the greater the mania/bubble the shorter the time frame of repair you can take on with reasonable risk with a point that yes the bubble is so high and fast you don’t go there (e.g. Miami right now).  Keep in mind the property is being bought distressed and below market, this is not someone buying at market hoping to flip a year later for more, which is pure speculation.  I represent parties that do this.  In my area the bubble started happening right when Covid shut down started, and is still going.  In December 2020 for example, I assisted in the purchase of a distressed home, for $146k.  It was a house that before the bubble a year before would probably sell in good condition for $160k, with the bubble my client estimated $200k or more.  The key why the client went ahead and did it is the client’s assessment was the repairs and improvement would take no more than 10 weeks and about $30k - pretty quick for a bubble to burst and burst $25k to go below $176k.   On another, in good condition with the bubble RE agents believed it would sell for just under $700k, but before the bubble $550k.  The party selling wanted $500k.  There were multiple interested fix and flip parties, but only one would pay more than $450k, and the reason being the repairs and improvement would cost at least $110k and would take at least 6 and maybe 8 months, and thus the risk the bubble could burst during the repair process was much greater - and the fix and flippers were factoring in that risk.
